Event.name: Waiting
Event.definition:
<def-root>A <fen>Protagonist</fen> delays a planned action because they cannot or do not want to proceed until an <fen>Expected_event</fen> occurs. The <fen>Expected_event</fen> may be evoked by reference to a <fen>Salient_entity</fen> that participates in it. If a <fen>Salient_entity</fen> is expressed, the <fen>Expected_event</fen> is typically the arrival of the <fen>Salient_entity</fen> at the <fen>Place</fen> where the <fen>Protagonist</fen> is located.
<ex><fex name="pro">The cat</fex> <t>waited</t> <fex name="pla">on top of the washer</fex> <fex name="Time">as Elmer popped the lid off the can of cat food</fex> and then pounded the can's contents onto the plate</ex>
<ex>The family was furious that <fex name="pro">their 84-year-old dad</fex> had to <t>wait</t> <fex name="dur">52 hours</fex> <fex name="pla">in the emergency room</fex>.</ex>
Although in both frames a Protagonist/Agent is not performing some desired action for some period of time, the use of wait.v in this frame is different from that in Holding_off_on in that Waiting prominently portrays a future event that will allow the Protagonist to proceed (with doing something), whereas Holding_off_on does not necessarily imply that there is some event or state-of-affairs that will allow the Agent to proceed, rather focussing on the action that the Agent is not yet taking.
</def-root>

Arg.name: Protagonist
Arg.definition:
<def-root>The sentient being who cannot proceed with their planned activities until a Salient_entity has arrived or an Expected_event has occurred.
<ex><fex name="pro">He</fex> politely <t>waited</t>, hat in hand, until he could speak.</ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Salient_entity
Arg.definition:
<def-root>A concrete or abstract entity that the <fen>Protagonist</fen> expects to participate in an <fen>Expected_event</fen>, typically that of arriving at the <fen>Place</fen> of the <fen>Protagonist</fen>.
<ex>In busier times several passengers are <t>waiting</t> <fex name="sal">for the train</fex>.</ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Time
Arg.definition:
<def-root>The time period during which the <fen>Protagonist</fen> is waiting.
<ex>At least 17 ships were <t>waiting</t> <fex name="Time">yesterday</fex> to come up the river.</ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Place
Arg.definition:
<def-root>The location in which the <fen>Protagonist</fen> is waiting.
<ex>Reporters are <t>waiting</t> <fex name="pla">outside the State Guesthouse</fex> for the talks to start .</ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Duration
Arg.definition:
<def-root><fen>Duration</fen> denotes the length of time from the beginning of the waiting to its end.
<ex>He <t>waited</t> <fex name="dur">for three hours</fex> this night, but no one showed up.</ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Manner
Arg.definition:
<def-root>Any description of the waiting event which is not covered by more specific FEs, including general descriptions comparing events (<ment>the same way</ment>) and salient characteristics of the <fen>Protagonist</fen> that also affect the action (<ment>patiently</ment>, <ment>anxiously</ment>).
<ex>She <t>waited</t> <fex name="man">tensely</fex> for him to appear</ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Expected_event
Arg.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Expected_event</fen> is an event that needs to take place or a state that needs to begin to hold before the <fen>Protagonist</fen> can proceed with their planned activities.
<ex>She did n't <t>wait</t> <fex name="exp_e">for a reply</fex>, but spelled out the answer herself.</ex> <ex>Then you have to <t>wait</t> about thirty seconds <fex name="exp_e">for there to be enough charge for a second jolt</fex>.</ex> <ex></ex></def-root>

Arg.name: End_point
Arg.definition:
<def-root>The point in time, defined either as a clock time or in terms of an event that takes place, at which the <fen>Protagonist</fen> ends the waiting.
<ex> I am willing to <t>wait</t> for him <fex name="end">until 10 o'clock</fex>.</ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Explanation
Arg.definition:
<def-root>The <fen>Explanation</fen> denotes a proposition from which the occurrence of the waiting event logically follows.
<ex>I <t>waited</t> for your brother to give me advice <fex name="Explanation">because I wasn't sure I was actually going to do this crazy thing</fex>.</ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Depictive
Arg.definition:
<def-root>This FE describes the <fen>Protagonist</fen> as being in some state during the waiting.
<ex>We <t>waited</t> <fex name="dep">with a smile on our faces and a chortle in our hearts</fex> when the race organizers handed out the first weather charts.</ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Purpose
Arg.definition:
<def-root>An action that the <fen>Protagonist</fen> intends to accomplish by waiting.
<ex>Cussing under his breath, he said he went back outside and <t>waited</t> quietly <fex name="pur">in order to avoid further argument</fex>.</ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Co-participant
Arg.definition: <def-root>Co_participant is an entity that participates in a coordinated way in the same event as the primary protagonist, regardless of whether the protagonist, and hence the <fex name="Co-participant">Co-participant</fex>, is more agent- or more undergoer-like.</def-root>

lexUnit.name: wait.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: stay where one is or delay action until a particular time or occurrence.

lexUnit.name: bide its time.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: to wait for an opportunity to do something
